task.title: Setting Up a Development Environment for Plugins

keywords.indexterm: Setting up a development environment for plugins

p.note: You will need a recent version of Eclipse EE.

context.p: This procedure describes a development environment that can be used to increase your productivity in writing plugins for .

Developing a plugin for might require repetitive code-testing cycles. Since the process of building a WAR file requires a full Maven build, the whole process might prove to be time consuming. The following procedure provides a faster alternative for testing the plugin:

step.cmd: Go to the following repository and follow the instructions: .
Run in a Tomcat server. You can either use one of the installation kits, the WAR distribution, or build it using the Web Author Component Integration sample project.

ul.li: If you are using one of the installation kits, you should disable file security to work with plugins in development mode.

If you are using the WAR distribution or the Web Author Component, you can start in Eclipse in debugging mode. This allows you to place breakpoints in your plugin's Java code and make live code changes. The procedure is as follows:
Import the .war application as a project in Eclipse:
File Import .
Choose Web WAR file .
Choose your .war file.
Click Finish.
On the new project, choose Debug On Server in the contextual menu then create a new server by choosing a server container supported by your version of Web Author, see Software Requirements topic. Before starting the server check that the Java version is also supported by opening Server view, double-click on the newly created server, the see the Runtime Environment configuration in the Overview tab.

info.note: If you choose to start Oxygen XML Web Author using the WAR (using Eclipse or directly putting the WAR in a Tomcat), please check that the Software Requirements are met.

step.cmd: Look in the Tomcat logs (or in the console) for a line like "Loading plugins from: ${path}" and note the path of the plugins folder.
In the plugins folder, create a sub-folder with a name of your choice (for example, myplugin).
In that folder (myplugin), create a plugin.redirect file that contains the path to your plugin project (created in steps 1 and 2) on a single line.
Import your plugin project in Eclipse.

substep.cmd: Browse for the location of your plugin.

step.cmd: Modify the plugin.xml file to add a library reference to the directory where Eclipse places the compiled output.
step.info: With the default setup of a Maven project, this step requires that you add the following element inside a runtime element:<library name="target/classes/"/>

step.cmd: You can now open a document in the and it will automatically load your plugin.
step.info: Every time you make changes to the plugin sources, you will need to restart .

postreq.p: If you are happy with the result, you can proceed with integrating the plugin into your SDK project and follow these instructions to perform a final testing of the project.
